segments.text: Following the hearings on the Laredo Transfer Bill in the House Higher Education Committee, it was pretty obvious that the bill was not going anywhere as far as the Higher Education Committee was concerned.
However, procedurally, there is a way to bypass the committee.
Would the Senate amend a House bill
and it be sent back to the House for concurrence, then the bill would not be going through committee.
It would have to be a bill that would be ruled as germane.
So we immediately set out to determine how many bills there might be that were germane or could be ruled germane.
to the subject of transfer of Laredo from A&M system to the University of Texas system.
One bill in particular that was germane was legislation that would transfer
the Baylor College of Dentistry into the Texas A&M University system.
This bill was out of committee in the Senate and was scheduled for debate on the Senate floor.
Fortunately, the supporters of the Baylor College of Dentistry in Dallas
became aware of the problem that could exist should their bill be amended and began to lobby to see that it was not amended.
I understand that the Lieutenant Governor took the position that the Baylor College of Dentistry bill would not be amended.
and later took the position that no amendments to transfer Laredo would be allowed on any of the bills as far as he was personally concerned.
This was fortunate because I think that the transfer of Laredo would have been viewed as a weakness on the part of the Texas A&M University system to allow this to happen.
and would have given the NM system a black eye for years to come.
We gained a position of some strength and the system was not tarnished.
In 1995, during the session, I was also asked to work with the new president of Prairie View
to help him become introduced and indoctrinated as to the Texas legislature.
I proceeded to introduce him to a number of key members of the legislature, one of which was the local state representative from Bryan.
The local representative was on the conference committee of the appropriations bill

and immediately took an interest in the programs at Prairie View and asked Dr. Hines to put together a proposal on very short notice to provide a summer intern program for high school students that wished to attend Prairie View.
They convinced the president we had very little time to do this and that the best way to do it was to do it with our
video telecommunication system hookup between Austin and Prairie View.
We went to the office, got on the system, and he was able to work a program up with his committee that was back on the campus in Prairie View, and in a very short time, a matter of hours,
get a proposal to our local state representative who was able to get it in the appropriations bill.
This kind of response is very important in working with the Texas legislature.
There's very little time in a legislative session to respond and react to
desires and wishes of the legislature.
A particular program and funding was not something that the president of Prairie View was asking for, but it was kind of dropped in his lap, so to speak.
There are good things that can happen during a legislative session.
if a person is there and is alert and understands the process and knows what he's doing.
No substitute, however, for turning out good students that the moms and dads will tell state legislators about and
therefore leaving an image of doing your work back home, i.e.
producing good students.
It's to be a cultivation of all members.
so that they will discuss issues with you freely and openly and even seek you out.
And this is something that takes a lot of time and effort to cultivate the members because there's a constant rotation of new members coming into the legislature each session.
There's been a strong believer in the use of our university presidents
in addition to the people that work at the system level.
These CEOs know their programs better than anyone and can present them to members of the legislature.
It should be a coordinated effort in that the system officials should be kept notified of what is going on.

There are conflicts between our system agencies and a system university, particularly Texas A&M University, but in each case these can be worked out and avoided if the interested parties are willing to work toward a compromise and let the system officials handle the issue.
The image of Texas A&M University affects all components of the system and for many years has been looked upon as the system.
Therefore, it's important that Texas A&M University's image be one of very highest regard as it reflects on everyone else.
On January 31, 1996, I retired from my position as director of public policy.
And 30 days later, accepted a part-time position with an agreement to perform a number of tasks
with regards to working with the legislators and maintaining the TAMIS Life program.
The tasks that were originally agreed to were later rejected by my supervisor.
And so for the past two years, time has been spent
for whatever task might be asked to perform.
In the meantime, I have found time to compile these memoirs.
Otherwise, it probably would not have been possible.
1996 was a red-letter year in another way.
The early 1980s
several members of my family, myself, and some friends chartered the Commerce National Bank in College Station and had been operating as a small independent bank since.
In 1996, we were contacted by
the Compass Bank Organization, headquartered in Birmingham, Alabama, and began negotiations with regards to a stock exchange merger.
Compass is a publicly held stock company that has branches in Alabama, Florida, and the eastern part of Texas.
The merger was finally consummated in April of 1997 for some delays in the approval process that one must go through with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The 1997 session the legislature saw me staying in College Station and monitoring the session over the internet.
The 1997 session was highlighted by the appropriations process going back to its
old ways of being written in conference committee.
No new dollars were added until the bill got to the conference committee.

New formulas were adopted in the Senate for higher education and finally approved in the conference committee, so very little was known about what was in the appropriations bill until it was finally written.
an old axiom that the more open government becomes, the more closed it will be.
In 1990, I'm sorry, 1979, we had been operating under a very open process in the conference committee, but we found a way to make the system work in conference committee when
there needed to be some private discussions.
I would meet with the Senate conferees in my office, and this did not constitute a quorum since I was only a member of one.
From time to time, I would invite another member

colleague in the house on the conference committee into the meeting always holding it no more than two of us so that there was never a quorum this was legal and we were able to conduct the business that needed to be conducted time a new legal approach was found
for 1997 by delaying all decisions until the conference committee met.
I seriously doubt that I could have gotten away, so to speak, with such a procedure in the time that I served as chairman of the Appropriations Committee.
I'm sure that we would have had an uprising and rebellion in the House
But times do change and legislators have become more tolerant.
Some latitude needs to be provided to legislature to meet in private sessions to consult on certain issues.
Under the present system, even salaries of key employees must be set in open session and discussed in such a setting.
In this environment, very little discussion takes place, and this is not in the best interest of good government.

The old saying that there are two things you don't want to watch, that is your sausage and your laws being made, was never truer than watching the appropriations process and how funds are allocated through the appropriations bill.
This is the end of the very last tape.
